 6           On appeal from a judgment of acquittal notwithstanding the verdict entered in the United
 7   States District Court for the District of Connecticut (Stefan R. Underhill, Judge), acquitting the

10   determination that the defendant not only had a buyer-seller relationship with the head of the
11   conspiracy but also knowingly and intentionally joined in and participated in the conspiracy, we
12   reverse and remand.

23   STRAUB, Circuit Judge:

24          The government appeals from the judgment of the United States District Court for the

25   District of Connecticut (Stefan R. Underhill, Judge), granting Defendant-Appellee Warren

26   Hawkins’s motion for an acquittal notwithstanding the verdict pursuant to Rule 29(c) of the

27   Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. The District Court found that, although the government

28   proved that Hawkins purchased cocaine from what he knew was a cocaine-distribution

29   conspiracy and that the head of the conspiracy knew of Hawkins’s intent to resell the cocaine, the

30   government’s evidence that Hawkins knowingly and intentionally joined and participated in that



            *
              The Honorable William K. Sessions III, Chief Judge, United States District Court for
     the District of Vermont, sitting by designation.

                                                      2
  1   conspiracy in violation of 21 U.S.C. §§ 841(a)(1) and 846 was insufficient. See United States v.

 2   Hawkins, No. 05-cr-058, 2007 WL 1732767 (D. Conn. June 15, 2007). For the reasons that

 3   follow, we find that the government’s evidence was sufficient to prove that Hawkins not only

 4   purchased from the conspiracy with a known intent to resell, but he knowingly and intentionally

 5   joined and participated in it. Accordingly, we REVERSE the judgment of acquittal and

 6   REMAND the case to the District Court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.

 7                                           BACKGROUND

 8          In a thirteen-count Superseding Indictment charging Hawkins and twenty-two others with

 9   various offenses, Hawkins was charged with one count of conspiring with Alex Luna, the head of

10   a drug organization, Joshua Febres, a Luna associate and the brother of Hawkins’s childhood

11   friend, Arcadio Ramirez, Jose Luis Rodriguez and others to possess with intent to distribute and

12   to distribute fifty grams or more of cocaine base and five kilograms or more of cocaine, in

13   violation of 21 U.S.C. §§ 841(a)(1), (b)(1)(A) and 846. In May 2006, Hawkins and two co-

14   defendants, Ramirez and Rodriguez, were tried before a jury on the conspiracy count. Hawkins

15   was found guilty of entering into a conspiracy to distribute less than 500 grams of a mixture or

16   substance containing a detectable amount of cocaine and/or less than five grams of a mixture or

17   substance containing a detectable amount of cocaine base. The jury also convicted Ramirez and

18   Rodriguez, finding them responsible for at least 500 grams and five kilograms of cocaine,

19   respectively.

20          At trial, the government presented evidence regarding a conspiracy led by Alex Luna to

21   distribute cocaine in Danbury, Connecticut from late 2002 until March 4, 2005, when Luna, his


                                                     3
  1   associate Febres, Hawkins and others were arrested. The evidence concerning Hawkins adduced

 2   at trial consisted of: (1) recordings of five intercepted telephone calls between Hawkins and

 3   members of the conspiracy; (2) the testimony of cooperating witness Febres; and (3) the

 4   testimony of Special Agent Eileen Dinnan of the Drug Enforcement Administration. We review

 5   this evidence in the light most favorable to the government.

 6          Members of the Luna conspiracy testified that an eight-ball of cocaine, approximately 3.5

 7   grams, could be broken down into several 0.3 gram bags for resale. An eight-ball, however,

 8   might also be bought for personal use.

 9          On February 9, 2005, Febres called Hawkins, a childhood friend of his sister. Hawkins

10   confirmed to Febres what it appears he suggested previously to Luna: that Hawkins wanted to

11   purchase five grams of cocaine from Luna. Febres told him the price would be twenty-three

12   dollars per gram. Hawkins asked about the quality of the cocaine, and Febres reassured him that

13   it was “official. Trust.” Febres passed the phone to Luna, who told Hawkins, “Come get your

14   shit, man.” Hawkins told Luna that he had recently seen Henry Mayoral, a member of the Luna

15   conspiracy. Hawkins then explained to Luna that he expected to sell his car in a few days and

16   planned to put some of the proceeds into savings and use the rest “to get fresh with.” Febres

17   testified that this meant Hawkins planned to purchase cocaine from Luna. Hawkins asked Luna

18   how he should get in touch with them and Luna instructed him to use the same number from

19   which Febres had just called him, Luna’s cellphone number. Hawkins said he would store the

20   number in his phone and call Luna later. Hawkins and Luna then chatted, with Hawkins

21   expressing his desire to “[s]tay under the radar” and “[s]tay away from them knuckle heads and


                                                     4
  1   that wild shit.” Hawkins said that he did “nothing but go to work and come home and chill with

 2   [his] kids and wifey,” who was pregnant. Hawkins then told Luna, “Give me like five or six

 3   little, little, little peoples to ride with. You know what I mean? So I could do whatever and uhm

 4   . . . .” Febres testified that this sale of five grams to Hawkins did not occur.

 5          On February 12, 2005, Hawkins called Luna and told him that two individuals from work

 6   were seeking drugs. “These kids . . . from work, like I got two . . . of them. Homie been calling

 7   me. He’s . . . looking hard, man.” Febres testified that “looking hard” meant the customer

 8   wanted to get high. Hawkins noted that he does not do business with the cocaine dealers on

 9   Beaver Street. Hawkins asked Luna about buying an eight-ball and they agreed Hawkins would

10   call Luna back later that day. Febres thought Hawkins might have been planning to get high with

11   his customers or to take some for his own use. Special Agent Dinnan conducted surveillance of

12   Luna that day and observed Hawkins meet with Luna in the parking lot of Hawkins’s

13   condominium. Febres testified that this sale of 3.5 grams of cocaine to Hawkins was completed.

14          On February 17, 2005, Luna called Hawkins. Hawkins asked Luna how much he wanted

15   for two eight-balls and Luna confirmed that the price was ninety dollars per eight-ball. The two

16   arranged to meet at a local ice-cream parlor. Febres went with Luna to deliver the cocaine to

17   Hawkins at the parlor. Febres testified that this sale of seven grams of cocaine to Hawkins was

18   completed.

19          On February 23, 2005, Hawkins called Luna and said that he was broke but he needed an

20   eight-ball. Hawkins explained that he had a potential customer:

21                  I got this white kid, he waiting for me right now, he got a $100.00.
22                  I need a “8 ball” though. You know what I mean? I need to come

                                                       5
  1                   from you right now and go give it to him and then hit you right
 2                   back in the spot. Whatever or just give you [unintelligible], I’ll get
 3                   back on my feet.
 4
 5   Febres explained that Hawkins was asking Luna for credit to resell an eight-ball to a customer

 6   from New Milford. Luna agreed with the plan, saying he would call him back. A few minutes

 7   later, Hawkins called Luna and asked for confirmation on the deal. Hawkins again said he would

 8   meet the customer, “grab the dough from him and come right back and hit you with it.” Luna

 9   told Hawkins to “go to the Gardens,” a Danbury housing complex, and Luna said he would “be

10   right there.” At this time, Luna, Febres and a co-conspirator were inside a parked car,

11   compressing cocaine. (Febres explained that this process entailed cutting the cocaine to decrease

12   its purity.) The credit transaction with Hawkins did not take place.1

13          Febres testified that Hawkins was an addict who bought drugs, and that he was neither a

14   drug dealer generally nor a member of the Luna organization. Febres accepted the government’s

15   characterization of Hawkins as a go-between.

16          At the close of the government’s main case, Hawkins and his co-defendants each moved

17   for a judgment of acquittal. The District Court denied the motions, explaining that with respect

18   to Hawkins it “is a closer call[,] but if the jury adopts the government’s view of the evidence . . .

19   I think they could return a verdict against Mr. Hawkins.”

20          The District Court charged the jury, instructing that on the element of membership in a

21   conspiracy the government must prove more than mere presence, association, and knowledge.

  1   As Hawkins requested, the District Court further instructed: “Thus, without more, the mere

 2   existence of the buyer/seller [relationship] is insufficient to establish membership in a

 3   conspiracy.” The District Court also instructed the jury on single versus multiple conspiracies,

 4   explaining that the government must prove the existence of the conspiracy charged in the

 5   indictment and each defendant’s participation in that conspiracy. The jury found Hawkins guilty,

 6   the District Court subsequently granted his Rule 29(c) motion, Hawkins, 2007 WL 1732767, and

 7   this appeal followed.

 8                                              DISCUSSION

 9   I. Standard of Review and Proof of Conspiracy

10          “We review the district court’s judgment of acquittal notwithstanding the verdict de

11   novo.” United States v. Espaillet, 380 F.3d 713, 718 (2d Cir. 2004). A defendant challenging the

12   sufficiency of the evidence that was the basis of his conviction at trial “bears a heavy burden.”

13   United States v. Parkes, 497 F.3d 220, 225 (2d Cir. 2007) (internal quotation marks omitted),

14   cert. denied, 128 S. Ct. 1320 (2008). On such a challenge, “we view the evidence in the light

15   most favorable to the government, drawing all inferences in the government’s favor and deferring

16   to the jury’s assessments of the witnesses’ credibility.” Id. (internal quotation marks omitted).

17   We will sustain the jury’s verdict “so long as ‘any rational trier of fact could have found the

18   essential elements of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt.’” Id. at 225-26 (quoting Jackson v.

19   Virginia, 443 U.S. 307, 319 (1979)). “In the application of this Rule to the conspiracy conviction

20   challenged here, we note that ‘[i]n cases of conspiracy, deference to the jury’s findings is

21   especially important . . . because a conspiracy by its very nature is a secretive operation, and it is


                                                        7
  1   a rare case where all aspects of a conspiracy can be laid bare in court with the precision of a

 2   surgeon’s scalpel.’” United States v. Wexler, 522 F.3d 194, 207 (2d Cir. 2008) (brackets in

 3   original) (quoting United States v. Morgan, 385 F.3d 196, 204 (2d Cir. 2004) (ellipsis in

 4   original)). We further note that “our sufficiency of the evidence test must consider the

 5   [g]overnment’s case in its totality rather than in its parts, and may be satisfied by circumstantial

 6   evidence alone.” Id. (citations omitted). Nevertheless, “specious inferences are not indulged

 7   because it would not satisfy the Constitution to have a jury determine that the defendant is

 8   probably guilty.” United States v. Lorenzo, 534 F.3d 153, 159 (2d Cir. 2008) (citation, brackets,

 9   and internal quotation marks omitted). “[I]f the evidence viewed in the light most favorable to

10   the prosecution gives equal or nearly equal circumstantial support to a theory of guilt and a

11   theory of innocence, then a reasonable jury must necessarily entertain a reasonable doubt.”

12   United States v. Glenn, 312 F.3d 58, 70 (2d Cir. 2002) (internal quotation marks omitted).

13          “To be guilty of conspiracy, there must be some evidence from which it can reasonably be

14   inferred that the person charged with conspiracy knew of the existence of the scheme alleged in

15   the indictment and knowingly joined and participated in it.” United States v. Snow, 462 F.3d 55,

16   68 (2d Cir. 2006) (internal quotation marks omitted), cert. denied, 127 S. Ct. 1022 (2007). “An

17   individual defendant’s membership in a conspiracy may not be established simply by his

18   presence at the scene of a crime, nor by the fact he knows that a crime is being committed.”

19   United States v. Desimone, 119 F.3d 217, 223 (2d Cir. 1997), cert. denied, 525 U.S. 874 (1998).

20   Nor is a defendant’s “mere association with those implicated in an unlawful undertaking

21   [sufficient] to prove knowing involvement.” United States v. Nusraty, 867 F.2d 759, 764 (2d


                                                       8
  1   Cir. 1989). “Evidence tending to show knowing participation in the conspiracy is also needed,

 2   i.e., facts sufficient to draw a logical and convincing connection between circumstantial evidence

 3   of an agreement, and the inference that an agreement was in fact made.” United States v. Jones,

 4   393 F.3d 107, 111 (2d Cir. 2004) (citation and internal quotation marks omitted); see also

 5   Desimone, 119 F.3d at 223 (“[M]embership requires proof of purposeful behavior aimed at

 6   furthering the goals of the conspiracy.”). Nevertheless, “[t]he government need not prove that

 7   the defendant[] knew the details of the conspiratorial scheme or the identities of all of the

 8   conspirators.” United States v. Downing, 297 F.3d 52, 57 (2d Cir. 2002). The defendant’s

 9   participation in the conspiracy with the requisite criminal intent may be established through

10   circumstantial evidence. Wexler, 522 F.3d at 208.

11   II. The Buyer-Seller Rule

12          A conspiracy conviction requires proof “that two or more persons agreed to participate in

13   a joint venture intended to commit an unlawful act.” Desimone, 119 F.3d at 223. “A transfer of

14   drugs from a seller to a buyer necessarily involves agreement, however brief, on the distribution

15   of a controlled substance from the former to the latter.” Wexler, 522 F.3d at 210 (Raggi, J.,

16   concurring in part and dissenting in part). However, while the illegal sale of narcotics is a

17   substantive crime requiring an agreement by two or more persons, “‘the sale agreement itself

18   cannot be the conspiracy [to distribute], for it has no separate criminal object.’” Wexler, 522

19   F.3d at 208 (alteration in original) (quoting United States v. Thomas, 284 F.3d 746, 751-52 (7th

20   Cir. 2002)). “Without more, the mere buyer-seller relationship . . . is insufficient to establish a

21   conspiracy.” United States v. Gore, 154 F.3d 34, 40 (2d Cir. 1998); see also Wexler, 522 F.3d at


                                                       9
  1   210 (Raggi, J., concurring in part and dissenting in part) (“Absent more, . . . the law does not

 2   consider this momentary meeting of the minds sufficient to support a conviction for conspiring to

 3   distribute drugs.”); United States v. Beech-Nut Nutrition Corp., 871 F.2d 1181, 1191 (2d Cir.)

 4   (“[A] mere buyer-seller relationship is not necessarily a conspiracy . . . .”), cert. denied, 493 U.S.

 5   933 (1989); United States v. Borelli, 336 F.2d 376, 384 (2d Cir. 1964) (“[A] sale or a purchase

 6   scarcely constitutes a sufficient basis for inferring agreement to cooperate with the opposite

 7   parties for whatever period they continue to deal in this type of contraband, unless some such

 8   understanding is evidenced by other conduct which accompanies or supplements the

 9   transaction.”), cert. denied, 379 U.S. 960 (1965); United States v. Koch, 113 F.2d 982, 983 (2d

10   Cir. 1940) (“The purchase of the cocaine from [a conspirator] was not enough to prove a

11   conspiracy in which [the seller] and the appellant participated. They had no agreement to

12   advance any joint interest.”).

13          “The rationale for holding a buyer and a seller not to be conspirators is that in the typical

14   buy-sell scenario, which involves a casual sale of small quantities of drugs, there is no evidence

15   that the parties were aware of, or agreed to participate in, a larger conspiracy.” United States v.

16   Medina, 944 F.2d 60, 65 (2d Cir. 1991), cert. denied, 503 U.S. 949 (1992). However, “[t]his

17   rationale does not apply . . . where, [for example,] there is advanced planning among the alleged

18   co-conspirators to deal in wholesale quantities of drugs obviously not intended for personal use.

19   Under such circumstances, the participants in the transaction may be presumed to know that they

20   are part of a broader conspiracy.” Id. at 65-66.

21          It is clear, then, that the existence of a buyer-seller relationship does not itself establish a


                                                        10
  1   conspiracy; however, where there is additional evidence showing an agreement to join together to

 2   accomplish an objective beyond the sale transaction, the evidence may support a finding that the

 3   parties intentionally participated in a conspiracy. See Wexler, 522 F.3d at 208 (noting, in the

 4   course of reversing conviction for narcotics-distribution conspiracy, the absence of proof of an

 5   agreement to distribute); Gore, 154 F.3d at 41 (holding that “it would be sheer speculation for

 6   jurors to conclude that an agreement to distribute drugs had been made” where there was no

 7   evidence “of the exact nature of [the sale] transaction or the quantity of drugs involved”);

 8   Beech-Nut Nutrition Corp., 871 F.2d at 1191 (“[A] defendant may be deemed to have agreed to

 9   join a conspiracy if there is something more, some indication that the defendant knew of and

10   intended to further the illegal venture, that he somehow encouraged the illegal use of the goods

11   or had a stake in such use.” (internal quotation marks omitted)); Borelli, 336 F.2d at 384

12   (“Purchase or sale of contraband may, of course, warrant the inference of an agreement going

13   well beyond the particular transaction. A seller of narcotics in bulk surely knows that the

14   purchasers will undertake to resell the goods over an uncertain period of time, and the

15   circumstances may also warrant the inference that a supplier or a purchaser indicated a

16   willingness to repeat.”); Koch, 113 F.2d at 983 (“It was necessary to the government’s case to

17   show that the appellant was in some way knowingly associated in the unlawful common

18   enterprise to import the drugs and dispose of them unlawfully.”).

19          Thus, where the evidence has supported the inference that a defendant agreed to

20   participate in the conspiracy beyond simply buying or selling we have upheld the conviction. For

21   example, in United States v. Miranda-Ortiz, 926 F.2d 172 (2d Cir.), cert. denied, 502 U.S. 928


                                                     11
  1   (1991), we rejected a sufficiency challenge brought by a defendant whose participation was

 2   limited to “a single transaction” because “the evidence permit[ted] an inference that the

 3   defendant had knowledge of the conspiracy and intended to join.” Id. at 176. In that case, there

 4   was evidence that the defendant had twice offered to sell narcotics to an alleged coconspirator

 5   and that “the two men exchanged beeper numbers.” Id. Although the defendant argued that this

 6   evidence suggested he “was merely offering to supply [the buyer] for his personal use,” we found

 7   that the jury could infer from the exchange of beeper numbers that the defendant suspected the

 8   buyer “was likely a distributor, rather than one who purchased only for his own personal use,”

 9   and that he had “sought to become [the buyer’s] partner in an ongoing narcotics operation.” Id.

10   The evidence surrounding an actual transaction further established that the two men had

11   conspired together to distribute cocaine. The coconspirator, unable to obtain cocaine for a repeat

12   customer from his normal supplier, sought to buy a kilogram of cocaine from the defendant. Id.

13   The defendant, certainly aware by now that this buyer was a distributor, sought reassurances that

14   the repeat customer was reliable. On that record, we held that the evidence “easily” satisfied the

15   element of participation and “was ample to permit the jury to infer beyond a reasonable doubt

16   that [he] knew of the ongoing conspiracy and joined it.” Id.

17          Similarly, in Medina, we held that the district court had not erred in refusing to give a

18   buyer-seller instruction to the jury because of the evidence of “advanced planning . . . to deal in

19   wholesale quantities of drugs obviously not intended for personal use.” 944 F.2d at 65. Such

20   evidence permits an inference that defendants are “part of a broader conspiracy.” Id. at 65-66.

21          On the other hand, in Gore, we held that a heroin seller’s statement that he did not “want


                                                      12
  1   to lose face with” his supplier established a buyer-seller relationship between the two, but was

 2   “standing alone . . . legally insufficient to show a conspiratorial agreement to distribute drugs

 3   made between [the defendant] and that unknown source.” 154 F.3d at 40. We acknowledged

 4   that the defendant’s statement “may imply more than one transaction,” but we held that “it would

 5   be sheer speculation for jurors to conclude that an agreement to distribute drugs had been made”

 6   in the absence of any “specific indication of the exact nature of that transaction or the quantity of

 7   drugs involved.” Id. at 41.

 8           Most recently, in Wexler, we held that there was insufficient evidence to support the

 9   defendant’s conviction for conspiring to distribute the painkiller Dilaudid, resulting in the death

10   of an alleged co-conspirator, because, although there was evidence that the two conspired to

11   distribute other painkillers to third parties, there was no evidence that the Dilaudid the defendant

12   helped supply “was redistributed or that there was ever any agreement or intention on the parts of

13   [the two individuals] to do so.” 522 F.3d at 208. We also noted that the quantities of Dilaudid

14   received “were consistent with personal use.” Id. The indictment specifically charged “that the

15   part and object of the conspiracy resulting in death was one to distribute Dilaudid, not a ‘variety

16   of drugs.’” Id. at 209. Thus, in the absence of “proof that [the recipient] agreed to, or did,

17   distribute Dilaudid, [the two individuals] were mere buyer-and-seller with respect to Dilaudid.”

18   Id. at 208.

19           The critical inquiry in each case is whether the evidence in its totality suffices to permit a

20   jury to find beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant was not merely a buyer or seller of

21   narcotics, but rather that the defendant knowingly and intentionally participated in the narcotics-


                                                       13
  1   distribution conspiracy by agreeing to accomplish its illegal objective beyond the mere purchase

 2   or sale.

 3              Evidence that a buyer intends to resell the product instead of personally consuming it

 4   does not necessarily establish that the buyer has joined the seller’s distribution conspiracy. This

 5   is so even if the seller is aware of the buyer’s intent to resell. It is axiomatic that more is required

 6   than mere knowledge of the purpose of a conspiracy. See, e.g., Direct Sales Co. v. United States,

 7   319 U.S. 703, 711-13 (1943); United States v. Ceballos, 340 F.3d 115, 124 (2d Cir. 2003). Such

 8   knowledge alone would not establish aiding and abetting liability, which requires proof of the

 9   intent to contribute to the success of the underlying crime, see United States v. Reifler, 446 F.3d

10   65, 96 (2d Cir. 2006), let alone conspiracy. See United States v. Lechuga, 994 F.2d 346, 349 (7th

11   Cir.) (en banc) (“A person who sells a gun knowing that the buyer intends to murder someone

12   may or may not be an aider or abettor of the murder, but he is not a conspirator, because he and

13   his buyer do not have an agreement to murder anyone.”), cert. denied, 510 U.S. 982 (1993);

14   United States v. Tyler, 758 F.2d 66, 70-71 (2d Cir. 1985) (reversing conviction for conspiracy to

15   distribute heroin of defendant who helped willing buyer find willing seller, but affirming his

16   conviction for aiding and abetting heroin distribution). Circumstantial evidence may, however,

17   support taking “[t]he step from knowledge to intent and agreement,” provided that “the evidence

18   of knowledge [is] clear, not equivocal.” Direct Sales, 319 U.S. at 711, 713; accord Ceballos,

19   340 F.3d at 124.

20              While we have avoided listing factors to guide what is a highly fact-specific inquiry into

21   whether the circumstances surrounding a buyer-seller relationship establish an agreement to


                                                        14
  1   participate in a distribution conspiracy, our sister circuits have identified several, including

 2   “whether there was prolonged cooperation between the parties, a level of mutual trust,

 3   standardized dealings, sales on credit (‘fronting’), and the quantity of drugs involved.” United

 4   States v. Hicks, 368 F.3d 801, 805 (7th Cir. 2004); United States v. Gibbs, 190 F.3d 188, 199 (3d

 5   Cir. 1999) (discussing several factors, including “the length of affiliation between the defendant

 6   and the conspiracy; whether there is an established method of payment; the extent to which

 7   transactions are standardized; and whether there is a demonstrated level of mutual trust”;

 8   “whether the buyer’s transactions involved large amounts of drugs”; and “[w]hether the buyer

 9   purchased his drugs on credit”), cert. denied, 528 U.S. 1131 (2000). The relevance of similar

10   factors has also been noted in our Circuit. See United States v. Wexler, 522 F.3d 194, 211 (2d

11   Cir. 2008) (Raggi, J., concurring in part and dissenting in part). No single factor is dispositive.

12   See Hicks, 368 F.3d at 805; Gibbs, 190 F.3d at 200. The dispositive inquiry remains whether a

13   rational jury could find beyond a reasonable doubt that a defendant has agreed to join and

14   participate in the conspiracy.

15   III. Evidence in this Case

16          In this case, the parties do not dispute that the government adequately proved that the

17   Luna conspiracy existed; that Hawkins knew of the Luna conspiracy; that Hawkins purchased

18   cocaine from Luna; that Hawkins intended to resell at least some of the cocaine he purchased

19   from Luna; and that Luna and Febres knew that Hawkins intended to resell some of the

20   purchased cocaine. See United States v. Hawkins, No. 05-cr-058, 2007 WL 1732767, at *3-4 (D.

21   Conn. June 15, 2007) (finding sufficient evidence of a Luna conspiracy, Hawkins’s knowledge


                                                       15
  1   thereof, and awareness by some Luna co-conspirators that Hawkins intended to resell cocaine).

 2   Hawkins does dispute, however, that he joined the conspiracy. He argues that he purchased the

 3   cocaine to use it, share it, or sell it, but it was only his business what he would do with it. The

 4   sole question, therefore, is whether the evidence was sufficient to permit a reasonable jury to find

 5   beyond a reasonable doubt that Hawkins intentionally joined and participated in the Luna

 6   conspiracy.

 7          In granting Hawkins’s motion, the District Court concluded that the evidence establishes

 8   at most that Hawkins acted as a “go-between,” i.e., one who facilitates sales between suppliers

 9   and users, without the intent “to further the goals of the conspiracy.” Id. at *7. The District

10   Court held that the government proved “that it [wa]s plausible that Hawkins joined the

11   conspiracy, but not that he joined the charged conspiracy beyond a reasonable doubt.” Id. at *9.

12          We find that the evidence was sufficient to support the jury’s finding beyond a reasonable

13   doubt that Hawkins knowingly and intentionally joined and participated in the Luna conspiracy.

14   After reviewing the evidence against Hawkins in its totality and in the light most favorable to the

15   government, we find that a rational jury could have found beyond a reasonable doubt that

16   Hawkins intentionally joined the Luna conspiracy by entering into a distribution agreement with

17   Luna himself that afforded Hawkins a source of cocaine and Luna another outlet — albeit small

18   — for his contraband.

19          In sum and as discussed further below, the evidence clearly establishes that Hawkins

20   intended to redistribute some of the cocaine he purchased or sought to purchase from Luna and,

21   moreover, that Luna and his associates knew this. In addition, the evidence supports the


                                                       16
